instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - dead with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>
threads.message:
Clean logic board, no oxidation, perfect!

I checked the main voltages, RTC and PCH. Only the <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 0v. I changed the <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> three times and same problem.

If I don't put the <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> on, it turns on!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - dead with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>
threads.message: Post all <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> voltages; when in place, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - dead with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - dead with <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> seems to be low, as <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> too.
<CHIP>U8130</CHIP> expects 3.07V at pin 2, in order to release <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>.
